channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coming Out in Lebanon
item.media:description: Alexander Paulikevitch, a dancer and choreographer, on the roof of his building in Beirut, Lebanon.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: Openly gay, lesbian and transgender people face persecution across the Arab world. The exception may be in Lebanon, which has slowly grown more tolerant thanks to the work of activists.
item.dc:creator: LAURA BOUSHNAK and MONA BOSHNAQ

item.title: ‘Massive Mental Health Crisis’ Feared for Rohingya Children
item.media:description: Gulbahar, a 25-year-old Rohingya Muslim, with her youngest daughter after arriving in Bangladesh in November.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: “I have nightmares that the military is chasing me,” says a 12-year-old who fled Myanmar. For hundreds of thousands like her, the horror isn’t over.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH

item.title: Even in Poland, Workers’ Wages Flow to North Korea
item.media:description: A shipyard, at right, in Police, Poland, where North Koreans have worked. The Polish government has pledged to phase out work permits for North Koreans, but the practice has persisted.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Defying Washington, a NATO ally hosts North Korean laborers, showing how difficult it is to sever the nuclear pariah state from the global economy.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN, CHOE SANG-HUN and JOANNA BERENDT
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rouhani Urges Calm in Iran as Protests Continue
item.media:description: Iranian riot police tossed smoke grenades on Saturday at a protest at Tehran University.
item.description: Two demonstrators were reported killed in recent days as protests quickly grew into a nationwide outpouring of anger.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Laughter, Then Horror, as Flames Engulfed Upscale Mumbai Restaurants
item.media:description: The fire in Mumbai, India, on Friday, destroyed two restaurants and left at least 14 people dead.
item.description: The fire at two restaurants on Friday killed 14 people. Patrons said the establishments had no fire alarms, sprinklers or clear emergency exits.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Merkel’s Wishes for 2018: More Empathy and a New Government
item.media:description: In her New Year’s address, an annual televised event, Chancellor Angela Merkel spoke about fears of a rift in German society.
item.description: In her New Year’s address, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany promised to work swiftly on a new coalition, and to help heal rifts in society.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Christian Democratic Union (Germany I'm pretty sure this must exist but I can't make it come up, apologies)

item.title: In Congo, 8 Killed and Altar Boys Arrested Amid Crackdown on Protests
item.media:description: President Joseph Kabila on a billboard in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo. As Mr. Kabila’s government has stalled in organizing elections, anger across the country has risen.
item.description: Churches had planned a peaceful march to protest President Joseph Kabila’s refusal to leave office, but security forces fired tear gas at churches and set up checkpoints in the capital.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE and STEVE WEMBI

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 17 at Funeral in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Maqam Khan cemetery outside Jalalabad, Afghanistan, on Sunday after a bomber detonated an explosive vest during the funeral of a former district chief.
item.description: The attacker, who was on foot, set off explosives in his vest among mourners gathered for the funeral of a former district chief at a cemetery in Nangarhar Province.
item.dc:creator: ZABIHULLAH GHAZI and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Romania Braces for President’s Decision on Bills Seen as Weakening Judiciary
item.media:description: Protesters marched in December in Bucharest, Romania, in support of the judicial system and against changes adopted by the governing coalition.
item.description: President Klaus Iohannis, who has long criticized efforts to weaken the fight against corruption, has 20 days to sign the measures into law or send them back to Parliament.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Kazakhstan Prizes Its Cowboys, but Few Want to Saddle Up for Harsh Life
item.media:description: Erlan Kozhakov, 63, a herder on the sandy scrub land between Kazakhstan’s biggest city and the Chinese border.
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.description: Kazakh cowboys, while proud of providing their rapidly modernizing nation with a link to its nomadic past, rarely want their children to follow them onto the frigid steppes.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: A Year of Animal Oddities Around the World: 7 Reader Favorites
item.media:description: A rare white giraffe and her calf in Kenya. Video of the animals was believed to be the first of its kind.
item.description: From rare white giraffes to criminal donkeys to chilly elephants, take a look at some of our strangest stories about animals in 2017 that resonated with readers.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Some Afghan Children Find an Alternative to Jail — for Now
item.media:description: Playtime at the Children’s Support Center in Kabul, an orphanage-like facility for children whose mothers are in prison, and that is in danger of losing its funding.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Orphanages for Afghan children of jailed mothers meet part of the need, but funding cuts threaten their future and many others stay in prison.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The U.S. Has Pummeled Al Qaeda in Yemen. But the Threat Is Barely Dented.
item.media:description: The scene of a suicide bombing this year in southern Yemen, where a branch of Al Qaeda has seized large swaths of land.
item.description: Despite tripling airstrikes this year, American officials concede an attack emanating from the chaotic, ungoverned spaces of Yemen remains among their top terrorism fears.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and SAEED AL-BATATI
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Origami-Style Cardboard Tents for Homeless in Brussels
item.media:description: One of the cardboard tents, known as the ORIG-AMI project, outside a Brussels train station on Friday. Material tents are banned on the city streets.
item.description: The entrepreneur behind the project hopes to give people somewhere safe to sleep in a city that bans material tents.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER

item.title: Amsterdam Journal: New Slaughtering Rules Pit Dutch Religious Freedoms Against Animal Rights
item.media:description: The Slagerij Marcus kosher butcher shop in Amsterdam. Jewish and Muslim groups have agreed to change ritual slaughter practices in the face of pressure from animal rights activists.
item.media:credit: Jasper Juinen for The New York Times
item.description: The authorities say the rules are intended to make kosher and halal slaughtering more humane, but some Jews and Muslims say they feel singled out.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: Australia Diary: We Will Carry You
item.description: He thought it was a fight, then the two Perth lifeguards showed up.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: A Year in Bloopers: The Making of The Daily 360
item.description: Happy New Year from the Daily 360 team! We've made 435 videos in 426 days. Here are some of the moments that didn’t make the cut. Pro tip: If you can see the camera, the camera can see you.

item.title: Greek Prime Minister Seeks to Block Asylum for Turkish Officer
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece, left, welcomes President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey during Mr. Erdogan’s two-day visit to Greece this month.
item.description: In an apparent effort to avoid antagonizing Turkey, Greece’s prime minister moved to block asylum for a Turkish officer who fled last year’s failed coup.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Congo Reports Arrest in Killing of 2 U.N. Experts
item.media:description: Zaida Catalan and Michael Sharp were abducted in March while investigating crimes in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.media:credit: Bertil Ericson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Timo Mueller/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The experts, Michael Sharp, an American, and Zaida Catalan, a Swede, were investigating crimes associated with a rebellion in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: STEVE WEMBI and JINA MOORE

item.title: Nepal Bars Solo Climbers From Mount Everest
item.media:description: Nepal, a Himalayan nation between India and China, has eight of the world’s 10 tallest mountains, including Mount Everest, center.
item.description: The action was an attempt to promote safety and reduce accidents, officials said, although some climbers said they intended to challenge the rule.
item.dc:creator: RAJNEESH BHANDARI

item.title: Iran Confronts 3rd Day of Protests, With Calls for Khamenei to Quit
item.media:description: A rally in support of the Iranian government in Tehran on Saturday. At rival protests in the capital on the same day, demonstrators directed their anger over the economy at Iran’s supreme leader.
item.description: As demonstrators called for Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, to step down, about 4,000 people in Tehran took part in an annual rally in support of the government.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Battle Royale Over Rightful Heir to Israeli Self-Defense Discipline
item.media:description: Haim Gidon, left, a claimant to the Krav Maga grandmaster title, at the beach in his hometown, Netanya, Israel. “Even with eye gouging, you have to know how,” he said. “You have to bring your thumb all the way in.”
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Krav Maga, which extols eye gouging and groin kicking, is a mainstay of military training and increasingly popular with civilians. Now, its founder’s disciples are sparring over who is the real grandmaster.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: The Look: Don’t Call It Street Style
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Jake Michaels for The New York Times; Andre D. Wagner for The New York Times; Daniel Arnold for The New York Times; Rose Marie Cromwell for The New York Times
item.description: This year, 21 photographers captured the ways we present ourselves to the world.
item.dc:creator: EVE LYONS

item.title: China to Try Tibetan Education Advocate Detained for 2 Years
item.media:description: Tashi Wangchuk faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of inciting separatism. He says he only wants the authorities to provide more Tibetan language education.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Tashi Wangchuk, who was detained after appearing in a New York Times video about Tibetan language education, faces 15 years in prison for inciting separatism.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The BBC in Pidgin? People Like It Well-Well
item.media:description: An article on the BBC website telling the story of a Tinder date gone wrong, written in West African pidgin English.
item.description: The British broadcaster, once a bastion of “received pronunciation,” has learned that if it wants to reach new audiences, it needs to try new approaches.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Pandas, U.F.O.s and Other Curiosities from Britain’s National Archives
item.media:description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan in the Oval Office in 1981.
item.description: British government memos, tweets and other documents find their way to the National Archives, with some released each year. Here’s a quirky look at Friday’s yield.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: 20 Great Reads You Probably Missed in 2017
item.media:description: A poster of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Istanbul.
item.media:credit: VII for The New York Times
item.description: With news breaking at a relentless pace, you might have missed some terrific articles The New York Times published this year. Here’s a selection.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: City of the Future? Humans, Not Technology, Are the Challenge in Toronto
item.media:description: A subsidiary of Google’s parent, Alphabet, plans to develop a futuristic neighborhood in Toronto.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Plans by a Google sibling for a development where robots collect trash and heated paths melt snow have generated excitement. But its data-collection sensors have spurred privacy concerns.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: The Bronx, New Year’s, I.R.S.: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Turkey Completes Deal to Buy Antimissile System From Russia
item.media:description: Turkish news media reported on Friday that Turkey would purchase four S-400 units from Russia at a cost of $2.5 billion.
item.description: The deal would make Turkey the first member of NATO to own Russia’s most advanced air defense system, and it has raised concerns among Turkey’s NATO allies.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Deaths in 2017: Among the Luminaries, Fighters With a Cause
item.media:description: Liu Xiaobo was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2010, while he was still in prison in China, for his efforts to promote democracy. He died on July 13.
item.description: Remembering Mary Tyler Moore, Chuck Berry, Jerry Lewis, Sam Shepard, Della Reese and many more, but also a remarkable roster of champions who pressed for change.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM McDONALD

item.title: Germans Will Ring in New Year With Extra Security, Especially for Women
item.media:description: Police officers closed off the area around the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin in preparation for the city’s New Year Eve festivities. Organizers have set up a “women’s safety area” for girls and women who have been assaulted or feel threatened.
item.description: Since attacks two years ago in Cologne, German cities, including Berlin, are setting up safety zones for women who feel threatened or have been assaulted.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Photographers’ Notebook: A Desperate Trek Toward Misery and Resignation: Capturing the Plight of the Rohingya
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees walk on a flooded trail to mainland Bangladesh.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Adam Dean and Tomas Munita, two photographers whose work appears regularly in The New York Times, describe their coverage of the crisis in Myanmar and Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: ADAM DEAN and TOMAS MUNITA

item.title: Scattered Protests Erupt in Iran Over Economic Woes
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in Parliament this month. Supporters hoped his re-election this year would lead to greater foreign investment in the country.
item.description: Demonstrations spread to Tehran and other cities, highlighting weak economic conditions in a country where youth unemployment is over 40 percent.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Liberia’s Vice President Concedes Election: ‘It Has Never Been About Me’
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph Boakai offered on Friday to aid the new government. “It has always been and should always be about Liberia,” he said.
item.description: Joseph Boakai offered to aid his opponent, George Weah, in setting the stage for the nation’s first peaceful transfer of power in decades.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: She Broke Japan’s Silence on Rape
item.media:description: Shiori Ito told the police she had been raped by Noriyuki Yamaguchi, then the Washington bureau chief for the Tokyo Broadcasting System and a biographer of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.description: She was a news intern. He was a TV journalist. She says he raped her, and she decided to do something Japanese women rarely do: Speak out.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: E.U. Hoped Balkan Border Deal Would Be Model for Peace. Then It Collapsed.
item.media:description: The border between Slovenia and Croatia near the village of Gibina, Slovenia.
item.description: Croatia refuses to recognize a ruling on its 26-year border dispute with Slovenia, leaving the bloc without a model for conflict resolution for other Western Balkan nations.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: A Cage Fighter With a Soft Touch for Hard-Core Jihadists
item.media:description: Usman Raja at the Fight Science gym in Aldershot, England. Over the last eight years, Mr. Raja, a former cage fighter, has helped reintegrate more than 50 released prisoners convicted of terrorism offenses.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Usman Raja, a former mixed martial arts fighting star, has earned international attention for his singular method of rehabilitating jihadists.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: We’re Not ‘National Hangover Service,’ N.H.S. Tells U.K. Drinkers
item.media:description: Bottles left for recycling in Bracknell, in southern England. “It’s frankly selfish” when paramedics and nurses have to be diverted to looking after those who have overindulged, said Simon Stevens, the chief executive of the health service in England.
item.media:credit: Steve Parsons/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The chief executive of the National Health Service in England said people who drank to excess were “selfish” and suggested greater use of drunk tanks.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Zimbabwean Family Lingers in Limbo at Thai Airport for 2 Months
item.description: The eight travelers, including children, are unwilling to return home because of political uncertainty and unable to secure visas to a third country.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and MUKTITA SUHARTONO
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: South African Court Raises Pressure for Zuma to Go
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa at an African National Congress meeting this month. Cyril Ramaphosa was elected there as the party’s new leader.
item.description: The court said Parliament had failed to hold President Jacob Zuma accountable in a corruption case and ordered lawmakers to set rules on impeachment.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Taiwan President Says China’s Military Expansion Could Destabilize Asia
item.media:description: Growing military pressure from China “is not just a situation that Taiwan faces,” President Tsai Ing-wen said at a news conference on Friday.
item.description: Her comments, made at a year-end news conference, underlined a commitment to self-defense just days after Beijing reiterated its goal of annexing the island.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: Gunmen Attack Cairo Church, Killing at Least 9
item.media:description: Gunmen attacked the Mar Mina Church in Cairo on Friday. Experts believe the assault to be the work of the Islamic State.
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the assault on a Coptic Orthodox Church, which was the latest in a wave of violence targeting the Christian minority in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: The Getaway: Visiting Windsor Before the Royal Wedding: A Guide
item.media:description: The upcoming marriage of Prince Harry and his fiancée, Meghan Markle, is generating a frenzy of interest among travelers.
item.description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will wed this spring just outside London, but why wait for the crowds to descend to soak up the royal atmosphere?
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM

item.title: How Did Bombs Made in Italy Kill a Family In Yemen?
item.description: We followed shipments of bombs from a holiday island in Italy to Saudi Arabia, then found those bombs at the scene of civilian deaths in Yemen. Is Italy capitalizing on a brutal conflict or just doing business?

item.title: Mumbai Restaurant Fire Kills at Least 14
item.media:description: The fire at an rooftop restaurant in Mumbai, India, on Friday killed at least 14 people.
item.description: A blaze engulfed two rooftop restaurants in Mumbai on Friday. The police filed criminal complaints against restaurant managers.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and HARI KUMAR

item.title: South Korea Seizes Ship Suspected of Sending Oil to North Korea
item.media:description: The Lighthouse Winmore, a Hong Kong-flagged vessel suspected of transferring oil to North Korea in violation of United Nations sanctions.
item.description: The seizure of the Lighthouse Winmore was revealed after President Trump accused China of secretly transferring petroleum to North Korean ships.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
